title: Miso Ramen (Sapporo Style Complete Bowl)
steps: Preheat your serving bowl by placing it in a 170°F (77°C) oven, or by filling it with hot water.
Prepare all toppings and have them ready (slice chashu, halve eggs, prepare corn and bean sprouts, slice green onions).
Bring a large pot of water to a rapid boil for cooking the noodles.
Heat the Doubutsu Kei Style Chintan broth to a simmer.
When ready to assemble, empty the preheated bowl and add the Ramen_Lord's Miso Tare (80g) to the bottom of the bowl.
Add the Ginger and Onion Pork Lard (30g) to the bowl.
Add the hot Doubutsu Kei Style Chintan broth (350g) to the bowl and whisk vigorously to fully incorporate the thick miso tare.
Cook the Sapporo Style Noodles (140g) in the boiling water according to the noodle recipe instructions.
When noodles are done, immediately drain them thoroughly in a fine mesh strainer, shaking vigorously to remove excess water.
Add the drained noodles to the bowl of soup. Use chopsticks to separate and arrange the noodles if desired.

Add toppings: place chashu at 6 o'clock position, egg at 11-12 o'clock, corn and bean sprouts on the sides, green onions in the center, and nori at 1-2 o'clock (add nori last as it gets soggy quickly).
notes: Component recipes needed: doubutsu-kei-chintan, ramen-lord-miso-tare, ginger-and-onion-lard, sapporo-style-noodle
Prepare all component recipes in advance before assembly.
This is a rich Sapporo-style miso ramen with a hearty, savory broth.
Alternative assembly method: Use the Sapporo Miso Wok Method where tare, lard, and some vegetables are stir-fried in a wok before adding soup.
The miso tare is thick, so whisking is essential to ensure even distribution in the soup.
Work quickly when adding noodles to prevent them from becoming sticky or overcooked.
80g of miso tare is thicker than liquid tare, 30 mL of lard equals approximately 30g, 350 mL of broth equals approximately 350g.
